race.name: PIRINEXUS 360
race.tagline: Trans-Pyrenean ultra-gravel through volcanic zones, medieval villages, and Costa Brava coast - Spain's answer to the 200-mile question

prestige.explanation: Part of UCI Gravel World Series and Gran Fondo World Tour Gravel Series. Sea Otter Europe integration adds legitimacy. 7 editions and growing - established as one of Europe's most respected ultra-gravel events, though not yet at Badlands-level iconic status.

race_quality.explanation: Well-organized with multiple food stations, medical assistance, and tracking via Track the Race. Sea Otter Europe backing provides professional infrastructure. Checkpoint-based format with route book/stamps adds brevet-style authenticity.

experience.explanation: Unforgettable journey from volcanic cones to Pyrenean passes to Mediterranean coast in a single push. The Col d'Ares crucible - 'a huge nightmare that breaks riders mentally and physically' - creates shared suffering. Night finish through singletrack toward Girona is legendary.

community.explanation: Growing community around the event, but primarily European. Sea Otter Europe festival brings 68,000+ visitors creating atmosphere. Girona's cycling culture provides welcoming infrastructure, but race-specific community not yet at iconic levels.

field_depth.explanation: Attracts experienced ultra-endurance cyclists from across Europe, but not major series or major pro field depth. Strong regional competition with international participants. Personal challenge format means less emphasis on elite racing.

value.explanation: Entry includes Sea Otter Europe festival access, multiple aid stations, finisher award, and festival services (bike cleaning, showers, expo). Reasonable for a 340km ultra event with full support infrastructure.

expenses.explanation: Girona offers reasonable European pricing. Budget flights to Barcelona or Girona from European hubs. Accommodation varies but available. No extreme remoteness premium. Total trip cost moderate by European standards - estimated $500-800 including travel from within Europe.

length.explanation: At 340 km (211 miles), this is true ultra-distance territory. Exceeds 150+ mile threshold significantly, placing it among the longest single-day gravel events in Europe.

technicality.explanation: Mixed terrain with 55% gravel. Via Verde sections are smooth, but the border crossing descent after Col d'Ares is genuinely technical - 'road simply disappears' requiring 40mm+ tires. Not extreme singletrack, but skill-demanding sections exist.

elevation.explanation: 3,400 meters (11,150 ft) of climbing with two significant passes: Coll de Coubet and Col d'Ares. The 70km section from Olot to Sant Joan features 900m of climbing alone. Relentless undulation throughout.

climate.explanation: September in Girona offers comfortable 20-25C temps, but 24% rain chance adds unpredictability. Night riding portion (final 2-3 hours for most) brings cooler temps. Col d'Ares summit significantly colder - hypothermia risk in wet conditions.

altitude.explanation: Maximum altitude at Col d'Ares is 1,513m (4,964 ft) - moderate elevation with minimal altitude effects. Start/finish at sea level in Girona. No significant altitude acclimatization needed.

logistics.explanation: Girona is the cycling capital of Europe with excellent infrastructure. Barcelona El Prat (118 km) offers international flights; Girona airport closer but limited. Sea Otter Europe festival sells out accommodation - early booking essential.

adventure.explanation: Exceptional scenic variety: La Garrotxa volcanic zone, Pyrenean border crossings, medieval villages (Peratallada, Pals), DO Emporda vineyards, Costa Brava coast. Crosses Spain-France border via ancient Roman Via Augusta. Night finish under the stars. Bucket-list European ultra.

distances.name: Pirinexus 360
distances.description: Full ultra-distance loop crossing Spain-France border via Col d'Ares

distances.name: Half Pirinexus
distances.description: Shorter challenge option with reduced climbing

history.origin_story: Created after Jordi Cantal completed the 340km Pirinexus route alone in 18 hours during summer 2014. What began as a personal challenge evolved into an organized event that has become 'one of the most authentic, beautiful, tough and prestigious gravel races in Europe.'

series_affiliation: Gran Fondo World Tour Gravel Series
key_features: La Garrotxa Volcanic Zone with 40 volcanic cones

weather.notes: One of the best cycling months in Girona. Night riding portion cooler. Summit weather unpredictable.

nearest_airports.name: Barcelona El Prat
nearest_airports.notes: Major hub, bus to Girona ~20 EUR

logistics.accommodation_notes: Book early - Sea Otter Europe brings 68,000+ visitors
logistics.bike_services: Girona is cycling capital of Europe - excellent shops, rentals, transfers

gear_recommendations.lights: 1000+ lumens front, rear light, spare batteries
gear_recommendations.clothing: Layers for 10-26C range, rain jacket mandatory
gear_recommendations.navigation: GPS with GPX, backup phone, route book

dnf_factors: Col d'Ares historically main DNF point

final_verdict.one_liner: The thinking rider's 340k—half the distance of the big ultras but twice as beautiful, with a border-crossing climb that sends half the field home early.
final_verdict.should_you_race: You need 200+ mile legs and 40mm+ tires minimum—the technical border descent after Col d'Ares will put narrower rubber on foot. This isn't a watts contest; it's navigation, bike handling, and knowing when to push through the Pyrenean climbs versus when to survive them. Show up undertrained and that 18-hour cutoff becomes very real very fast.
final_verdict.alternatives: Gravel Worlds in Nebraska gives you similar distance with half the climbing and none of the charm. Dirty Kanza (Unbound) trades European scenery for American suffer-fest purity, while Eroica keeps the Old World vibe but loses the modern challenge.

course_description.character: The Pirinexus is half smooth greenway cruise, half bike-destroying nightmare. You'll roll 55 kilometers on the silky Via Verde del Carrilet thinking this is easy, then spend the next 70 kilometers climbing volcanic hills and technical gravel that'll have you questioning your tire choice. The route crosses into France where the road literally disappears into rocky descents that punish anything under 40mm tires.

suffering_zones.label: La Garrotxa Volcanic Reckoning
suffering_zones.desc: The greenway party ends and reality hits. Seventy kilometers through volcanic terrain with 900 meters of climbing, starting with Coll de Coubet—a 9km grind that gives no respite.

suffering_zones.label: Col d'Ares Death March
suffering_zones.desc: The 17.9km border crossing at 1,513 meters where dreams die. This is where most DNFs happen and the mental breaking point that separates finishers from the field.

suffering_zones.label: French Descent Carnage
suffering_zones.desc: After grinding to the border, the road disappears into technical rocky descents. Riders on narrow tires walk while suspension bikes roll past laughing.

suffering_zones.label: Costa Brava False Hope
suffering_zones.desc: The coast looks like relief but delivers rolling agricultural roads and hidden climbs. Your legs are already cooked and there's still 50 miles of punishment ahead.

course_description.signature_challenge: Col d'Ares is the course executioner—a 17.9-kilometer climb to the French border that peaks at 1,513 meters. It's not just the elevation; it's arriving there after 80 miles of volcanic punishment, knowing that technical descents await on the other side. Most riders call it quits here, and the ones who don't spend the descent walking their bikes down rocky trails that shouldn't exist on a cycling route.

unsplash_photos.description: a river running through a city next to tall buildings
a river running through a city next to tall buildings
